Description: Body sherd of Laconian black-figured pottery stemmed kylix; dull cream slip; interior: black-figure decoration consisting of part of snake and beard of Gorgoneion; exterior: band of rays and one of outlined tongues (some with added red dots at their centre), separated by groups of narrow and wide black bands with added red.
Curator's comments: Object owned and held by the Greco-Roman Museum, Alexandria. This record is included in the British Museum database as part of the Museum’s Naukratis Project, a research collaboration that aims to virtually re-unite finds from the ancient port city of Naukratis, now distributed over 80 museums worldwide.

Venit attributes the cup to the Boreads Painter on the basis of the subject matter and the almost identical incision marks found on another cup attributed to the same painter. See British Museum 1888,0601.523.
Bibliographic references: Venit 1988 / Greek Painted Pottery from Naukratis in Egyptian Museums (p. 114-5, pl. 84, no. 400)
Möller 2000 / Naukratis, Trade in Archaic Greece (p. 240)
Venit 1985 / Laconian Black Figure Pottery in Egypt (p. 393, pl. 43, no. 12-13)
Venit 1982 / Painted Pottery from the Greek Mainland found in Egypt, 640-450 BC (p. 551, no. E 13, pl. XXXIX, pl. CCLXII)
Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (GC.64) (phase 3)
